Sentence: [00:00.000 --> 00:07.320]: Hello? Good morning, this is Dr. Smith from the Brigham and Women's Hospital Obstetric
[00:07.320 --> 00:15.960]: Anesthesia team. I'm looking for Ms. Jane Blank. This is her. Great, good morning. Your obstetrician
[00:15.960 --> 00:21.080]: asked our team to reach out with you to chat about some anesthesia-related considerations,
[00:21.080 --> 00:26.840]: given some of your history. Do you have 10 to 15 minutes to speak with us? Yeah, sure. Great.
[00:26.840 --> 00:32.880]: We've reviewed your chart. We'd just like to review your history, discuss some of the findings
[00:32.880 --> 00:41.420]: from the current pregnancy, and talk a little more about your obstetric history. Okay. Great.
[00:41.420 --> 00:47.840]: So, looking at the ultrasound, it looks like you have some placenta previa, is that correct? Yes.
[00:47.840 --> 00:53.460]: Very good. Based on that ultrasound, it doesn't show any other abnormalities with the placenta,
[00:53.460 --> 00:56.340]: like placenta accreta. Is that correct, as far as you're aware?
[00:56.840 --> 01:05.600]: I was not told anything more than that. Perfect. Otherwise, it looks like the fluid around the baby
[01:05.600 --> 01:11.180]: is normal. The baby is normal size. I mean, you don't have any history of fibroids. Does all of
[01:11.180 --> 01:16.580]: that seem correct? Yeah. Very good. Otherwise, in this pregnancy, do you have any history of
[01:16.580 --> 01:26.480]: anything like preeclampsia? No. Very good. Are you taking any blood thinners at all? Yes. I
[01:26.840 --> 01:37.460]: do. I started taking Lovenox during the pregnancy because I previously had a clot.
[01:37.460 --> 01:47.500]: Okay. How long ago was that clot? It was about 10 years ago, but I was taking the pill then.
[01:47.500 --> 01:56.680]: Okay. I see. You were only in Lovenox during the pregnancy? Yes. Okay. Very good. Has your OB team
[01:56.840 --> 02:00.220]: talk to you about the plan for the Lovinox as you get closer to delivering?
[02:00.740 --> 02:05.640]: They mentioned that they would switch me to another medication.
[02:06.020 --> 02:12.760]: I forgot what it was, but that would be later after 36 weeks.
[02:15.020 --> 02:17.760]: Often they transition to a medication called heparin.
[02:19.340 --> 02:20.860]: Yeah, that's what they said.
[02:21.380 --> 02:27.820]: Um, we'll check your obstetrician notes and, um, coordinate with them, but typically we
[02:27.820 --> 02:32.720]: change to heparin and then give instructions on when to stop prior to you coming in.
[02:35.380 --> 02:41.140]: Um, otherwise, just based on looking at your labs, your hemoglobin is 10 and your hematocrit
[02:41.140 --> 02:43.580]: is 30 and your platelet count is 180.
[02:43.740 --> 02:47.160]: So those are all within expected limits, um, during pregnancy.
[02:48.160 --> 02:51.360]: Um, I'm going to ask you a little bit more about your prior obstetrics.
[02:51.380 --> 02:52.580]: History, if that's okay?
[02:54.100 --> 02:56.540]: Um, I know you've never had a C-section before, correct?
[02:56.980 --> 02:58.680]: Yeah, it was all vaginal deliveries.
[03:02.600 --> 03:04.580]: Um, how many prior vaginal deliveries total?
[03:04.580 --> 03:07.380]: Uh, I've, uh, I had three children.
[03:08.900 --> 03:10.520]: Did you have epidurals for those?
[03:10.600 --> 03:12.380]: Yeah, I had epidurals for all.
[03:13.180 --> 03:14.460]: Any issues with those epidurals?
[03:14.620 --> 03:16.160]: Uh, no, everything worked great.
[03:17.800 --> 03:20.980]: Um, I know that you have a history of a...
[03:21.380 --> 03:22.740]: bleeding after one of your deliveries.
[03:25.020 --> 03:35.500]: After, uh, my, uh, son was born last time, um, I had some, um, problems and, uh, more
[03:37.640 --> 03:42.480]: Uh, from what I see here, it looks like you had a little bit of bleeding kind of after
[03:43.420 --> 03:44.240]: It was a little bit delayed.
[03:46.020 --> 03:50.840]: They said that, um, there were some pieces of, uh, placenta left.
[03:51.380 --> 03:53.100]: Yes, that's what I see here.
[03:53.320 --> 03:58.500]: Um, it looks like you've had about 1.2 liters from, um, some retained products.
[03:58.960 --> 04:02.080]: And did you have a, a DNC procedure to help with that?
[04:02.220 --> 04:04.600]: Yeah, I, I had to come in the hospital.
[04:06.060 --> 04:08.980]: Um, have you, I had any other DNCs in the past?
[04:12.500 --> 04:17.120]: I think it was, uh, one, one time.
[04:18.800 --> 04:21.220]: Any other history of any procedures on your uterus?
[04:21.380 --> 04:24.280]: Any other injuries on your uterus, like a hysteroscopy or a myomectomy?
[04:28.520 --> 04:37.520]: I had an, uh, append, appendicitis, and that was, uh, taken out by surgery many years
[04:40.060 --> 04:42.320]: Any other surgeries in your abdomen or pelvis?
[04:45.200 --> 04:48.660]: Otherwise, just by looking at your history, it looks like you don't have any history of
[04:48.660 --> 04:50.540]: any placenta accreta in the past?
[04:51.500 --> 04:53.760]: No history of any uterine rupture or inversion?
[04:56.120 --> 04:59.440]: Um, we talked about you having a history of the DVT.
[05:00.000 --> 05:03.500]: Otherwise, no other known bleeding or clotting disorders?
[05:05.480 --> 05:07.680]: Um, and have you ever had a blood transfusion?
[05:10.200 --> 05:13.360]: And this is pregnancy, did you utilize IVF for this pregnancy?
[05:15.280 --> 05:19.520]: Um, we're just going to ask a little bit more about your other baseline history, if that's
[05:21.140 --> 05:23.120]: Um, do you have any heart problems?
[05:26.160 --> 05:27.520]: Any high blood pressure?
[05:32.580 --> 05:35.560]: And how have you been doing with activity levels during this pregnancy?
[05:35.760 --> 05:37.620]: Um, generally it's been okay.
[05:39.640 --> 05:43.000]: You're okay walking around, doing your daily activities?
[05:43.640 --> 05:44.460]: Getting up the stairs?
[05:46.060 --> 05:47.340]: Are you allergic to any medications?
[05:51.140 --> 05:54.980]: Does anyone in your family have any history of anesthesia-related problems?
[05:55.980 --> 05:56.980]: I don't know of anything.
[05:57.980 --> 05:58.980]: Do you have any scoliosis in your back?
[05:59.980 --> 06:00.980]: Any procedures or any hardware in your back, as far as you're aware?
[06:03.980 --> 06:04.980]: So, um, for this placenta previa, I understand the plan will be for a cesarean section, as
[06:05.980 --> 06:06.980]: Um, and I understand this is your first time having a C-section, right?
[06:06.980 --> 06:07.980]: Well, the doctor said that if, um, it's a C-section, it's a C-section, it's a C-section,
[06:07.980 --> 06:08.980]: it's a C-section, it's a C-section, it's a C-section, it's a C-section, it's a C-section,
[06:08.980 --> 06:09.980]: it's a C-section, it's a C-section, it's a C-section.
[06:09.980 --> 06:11.120]: Well, the doctor said that if, um, it may, uh, improve, and if that's the case, I can
[06:11.120 --> 06:12.120]: have vaginal delivery.
[06:14.120 --> 06:15.140]: Um, we just want to talk to you a little bit more about our considerations, uh, for
[06:15.140 --> 06:16.140]: patients who have placenta previa and some other comorbidities, okay?
[06:17.140 --> 06:18.140]: So, given that you're having a C-section, what positive changes or negative changes
[06:19.140 --> 06:20.140]: So, I understand that you're having a C-section, and what positive changes do you feel
[06:22.140 --> 06:23.140]: So, for this placenta previa, I understand the plan will be for a cesarean section,
[06:24.140 --> 06:31.780]: have a vaginal delivery but otherwise yes got it um we just want to talk to you a little bit more
[06:31.780 --> 06:37.860]: about our considerations uh for patients who have placenta previa and some other comorbidities okay
[06:37.860 --> 06:43.520]: so given the previa itself as well as some of your history including your history of a bleed in the
[06:43.520 --> 06:49.900]: past um you're at higher risk than most for bleeding surrounding the time of delivery
[06:49.900 --> 07:00.840]: um so we just want to talk about our plan on our end um so for patients um when we do c-sections
[07:00.840 --> 07:05.800]: uh generally we do these under what's called neuraxial anesthesia either a spinal or epidural
[07:05.800 --> 07:12.120]: i know you're familiar with the epidural which helps keep you comfortable and um
[07:12.120 --> 07:19.060]: using a little epidural catheter and if everything improves and you have another vaginal delivery
[07:19.900 --> 07:25.820]: could do another epidural for you if we do a cesarean section we typically do it under what's
[07:25.820 --> 07:31.560]: called a spinal anesthetic which is very similar to an epidural but rather than being a small
[07:31.560 --> 07:36.360]: catheter it's a single shot injection into the spinal space that gets you numb for the surgery
[07:36.360 --> 07:44.020]: okay they're very similar um in terms of how they're placed um but those are basically the
[07:44.020 --> 07:47.960]: two options we can also do what's called a combined spinal epidural where you get the
[07:47.960 --> 07:49.880]: injection as well as a catheter that goes through the epidural and then you can do a
[07:49.900 --> 07:54.140]: spoke to do that and then a secondary section goes into the epidural space
[07:54.140 --> 07:57.060]: depending on the plan we will do one of those but most likely it'll be a spinal for a cesarean
[07:57.060 --> 08:06.180]: section okay okay um now there are some other considerations we have for patients at higher
[08:06.180 --> 08:15.880]: risk of bleeding we want to have good iv access as you know we have iv an iv place during the labor
[08:15.880 --> 08:19.740]: process and to help give you fluids and other medications if you're at a higher risk of bleeding
[08:19.740 --> 08:23.800]: we often replace a second IV to make sure we have good access ahead of time.
[08:23.800 --> 08:30.540]: Okay. Okay. We may use an ultrasound to help locate some bigger veins. We might
[08:30.540 --> 08:35.100]: use some numbing medication to help make the procedure less uncomfortable. Okay.
[08:35.100 --> 08:43.420]: Okay. Now if you do have some higher than normal bleeding during the delivery or
[08:43.420 --> 08:47.340]: during the cesarean section, there's medications that we can give that can
[08:47.340 --> 08:52.260]: help stop the bleeding by helping your uterus to contract or to help prevent
[08:52.260 --> 08:58.560]: the breakdown of clots in your blood. So most of those are acceptable for you.
[08:58.560 --> 09:02.820]: Given your clotting history, we would probably avoid one of them called
[09:02.820 --> 09:10.060]: tranexamic acid, which can basically help with extra clotting. Okay. Okay. But
[09:10.060 --> 09:16.020]: the other medications we can give you to help prevent or improve the bleeding
[09:16.020 --> 09:17.320]: that's happening. Okay.
[09:17.320 --> 09:24.720]: Okay. Now and sometimes in these events we need to give blood transfusions. Are
[09:24.720 --> 09:29.200]: you okay receiving blood only if necessary? Yeah, my doctor mentioned that
[09:29.200 --> 09:37.420]: this can happen. Okay. Fantastic. Some other interventions we include include
[09:37.420 --> 09:42.620]: what's called an arterial line, which is a special IV that goes into the artery
[09:42.620 --> 09:46.420]: rather than the vein to monitor the blood pressure. We only do that if we're
[09:46.420 --> 09:47.300]: in a situation where we're in a situation where we're in a situation where we're
[09:47.300 --> 09:53.060]: having kind of continued bleeding and we need closer monitoring of your blood
[09:53.060 --> 10:01.280]: pressure rather than cycling a cuff. Okay. So we may consider that at some point in
[10:01.280 --> 10:07.940]: the process. Now if things progress further, we may need to convert to what's
[10:07.940 --> 10:12.360]: called general anesthesia, which is where you're completely asleep. We place a
[10:12.360 --> 10:17.180]: breathing tube while you're asleep to help with your breathing. It's similar to what you had for the appendectomy.
[10:17.300 --> 10:22.540]: We only do that if we get into a situation where intimate bleeding continues and we
[10:22.540 --> 10:26.920]: need a little bit more control, or if you're having some discomfort. Okay.
[10:26.920 --> 10:33.060]: than ultimately if we do that the goal is always to have your sleep
[10:33.060 --> 10:38.960]: only for during the procedure itself. Now if you are still are needing a little
[10:38.960 --> 10:42.420]: bit more fluids, or more blood products to be given,
[10:42.420 --> 10:46.860]: and you're not quite stable enough to wake up, we'll keep you asleep and sedated with asescent, andство sedated with the sedation.
[10:47.300 --> 10:53.780]: breathing tube in and take you to a monitored unit such as an ICU until you're more stable.
[10:53.780 --> 10:57.780]: At that point of the men they would wake you up and we would take out the breathing tube.
[10:57.780 --> 11:02.820]: Okay. That's a very very rare scenario. I don't anticipate that for you but we want to give you
[11:02.820 --> 11:07.140]: a good idea of all the things that we are considering and preparing for just in case
[11:07.140 --> 11:12.660]: you have an abnormal amount of bleeding. Okay. Okay. That was a lot of information.
[11:12.660 --> 11:18.420]: What questions do you have for me? I don't have any questions at this time.
[11:18.420 --> 11:23.380]: Okay. Very good. Before we let you go, we're going to briefly have you speak with Dr. Jones,
[11:23.380 --> 11:26.900]: one of the attending anesthesiologists here at the Brigham and Women's Hospital. Okay?
[11:26.900 --> 11:32.820]: Okay. Hi, Ms. Blank. This is Dr. Jones. I'm one of the obstetric anesthesiologists here at
[11:32.820 --> 11:37.780]: Brigham and Women's. I read your chart and I was listening along with the conversation with Dr.
[11:37.780 --> 11:42.420]: Smith. It sounds like he mentioned some of our considerations for patients who have a higher
[11:42.420 --> 11:42.500]: risk of breast cancer than those who have a higher risk of breast cancer than those who have a higher
[11:42.500 --> 11:42.660]: risk of breast cancer than those who have a higher risk of breast cancer than those who have a higher risk
[11:42.660 --> 11:44.500]: of breast cancer than those who have a higher risk of bleeding. I just want to make sure you
[11:44.500 --> 11:49.300]: don't have any more questions about anything before we hang up. No, I'm all set for now.
[11:50.020 --> 11:54.660]: Okay. Very good. We'll document everything we discussed on this phone call in a note in your
[11:54.660 --> 12:01.700]: chart so that the team taking care of you knows what we talked about. That should be it. Otherwise,
[12:01.700 --> 12:12.500]: we'll be sure to keep you safe and comfortable. Thank you. Bye-bye. Have a nice day. Bye.
